title: How long does it take to write 30000 words? - Quora

response.answer_text: I notice the other answers so far are about typing speed. But I think the asker wants to know about writing speed, which isn’t the same thing. It’s almost infinitely variable, as each author writes at the their own speed. Some authors put in a 6 to 8 hours writing day, and write 10,000 words. Others will write for the same time and only put out 5000 words. So for the first, you’d be looking at 3 days, for a total of 18 to 24 hours work. The latter would double that to 6 days and 36 to 48 hours work. But for authors who write say 2000 words in 3 hours each day, this extends to 15 days. Slower writers will take longer. Now if one takes the question further, to how long does it take to write a novel, we get this: 10,000 words a day yeilds a 60k novel in 6 days, or a 90k novel in 9 days. 5,000 words a day yeilds a 60k novel in 12 days, or a 90k novel in 18 days. Depending on how much editing and proofing is needed, either can have a book released monthly, and the 10k a day people can have 2 books out a month (and do). 2,000 words a day yeilds a 60k novel in 30 days, or a 90k novel in 45 days. The 60k can be released every 6 weeks, and the 90k every 8 weeks. A bit of variability depending on if the author writes every day or not. A lot do.

What a timely question. I was just sitting here thinking about this very thing. I ponder if Quora is reading my mind… *crackles knuckles, and listens to the groans of my constant readers… If I’m transcribing, 1.5 to 2 days. It’s what I do. I’m transcribing around 4000 words an hour, averaged over five-six hours. My body and brain cannot physically handle more than 20,000 words. I can, in reality. But I really pay for it for a few days to a week later. Every once in a while I make a miscalculation or I forget what day it is and have to panic to meet a deadline. It takes about 5–7 hours to hit 20,000 words. It takes another 4–5 hours to get that last 10,000 words in, and then proof, and then I’m worthless for a week. …30,000 words in a day makes my brain really mushy. To make the math simple — 100 words a minute. Maximum 6000 words an hour. You’d have to maintain that pace, rhythm and focus for five solid hours. It’s one of those things when you see on paper, but when you sit down to do it, to type words and word patterns you’ve never seen or heard before — to think anybody can do that, that’s insanity. I’m sure there’s one or two people out there who are that .0001%, but for the rest of us mortals, that’s crazy. … But! This week, I started a new job for Metta Center for Nonviolence--Promoting Nonviolence Worldwide. Like filled out a payroll form, like kinda ‘officially started a new job,’ started a new job. I haven’t been on anybody’s payroll in over five years. I’ve been freelancing and unmanaged, working out of Canada and everywhere. It’s not really even a new job. It’s a job I’ve already been doing, but at the moment, they have enough work and funding to pay me, and filling out a payroll form made it easier for us. (Please feel free to donate to them!! This is NOT a lucrative gig for anybody.) Today, I hit 15,000 words, did a few administrative things, had to adjust an audio, and upload a fresh version, tweaked some macros that were bugging me. And now 120 minutes of video is searchable by text/ready to be used as captions, as well as a nice to read document. That’s a good workday, with adequate breaks and a lunch in there. …and my brain isn’t that mushy. I really could have done more. …I have a few months of work ahead of me, that I’ve been begging to do…now I have it! Ack! What have I done!! 30,000 words might be achievable in 7–9 hours — because I’ve typed millions of words for these folks and know their lingo, single speaker, spectacular audio. (Although he’s the most challenging guy I’ve ever transcribed. He throws in words from so many different languages, it confuses my google. You’d think both google and I would know what he’s saying by now. But no, we don’t. He keeps me on my toes like no other.) Plus, this is old archived stuff from 10 years ago. It’s almost amusing now and not traumatic…especially amusing, because I still have to google stuff to remember how to spell names and cities and things.  There’s always a glitch in the process or some lengthy distraction that rips apart my ability to focus. It’s really challenging for everything to go right and hit that 20,000 mark before I’m utterly exhausted and need a nap. But that’s another thing with this new gig. There’s no deadlines. There’s a MOUNTAIN of files that need to be transcribed, as well as other things. I don’t have to worry so much about what files I’ll be hearing next or how we’re going to eat next month. I’ve been pecking on these files for a few weeks already, but my ears had to go off to a refugee camp in Uganda and that mess is still working it’s way out through my pores. I need to be hitting 30,000 words a day. I don’t know how to explain it… I don’t know how anybody can physically do that. …30,000 words is a lot o’ words to hear, read, type, and proof…it’s a lot, y’all. Especially when the files are heavy and not about very pleasant things. … But at the end of it, I’ll have built my version of a metta metabase. It’s so very much meta metta. It looks bad right now, but it’s slowly growing. I haven’t had time to count all the words, because my prior organization system was a mess and I didn’t know what I was doing. Oh, it just needs layers! Seriously, the secret to good art, is layers. (Nobody knows what I’m doing. I’m fairly certain nobody has ever done things the way we’re doing things…and nobody really seems to understand why I’m still around, doing things — including myself.) And I know what I’m making. I’m slowly learning the art of wordcraft. Instead of test tubes or chemicals of the alchemist, the material I have gathered is the wordsmith’s proverbial gold and dynamite. I know it’s in there. I’m just not sure how to get it out, yet. Maybe it’s my weird version of a work of art that only a few will ever see. But golly, seeing the mammoth amount of metta data…it’s really gonna be a cool thing, well, almost a cool thing. I still have no clue what I’m doing and just kinda making stuff up as I go. It’s like a digital painting, but with other people’s words. Every keystroke, is like a brushstroke, is it not? It’s truly the art of a scribe, trying to show my species how much I love them, despite their wickedness. It looks like a simple spreadsheet at first, but then you get deeper, and deeper, and deeper, down to the letter — and the enormity of it smacks you in the face and it becomes so hard to comprehend. Personally, I’m finding it kinda impressive that all of that came from the same fingertips. It’s a ginormity amount of amazing words. …I think I can do 30,000 words in a day. There’s some blank spaces that need some color. It’s not even 1/2 way there. I think it’s currently over a million words. But if I can get this next section out of the way, then I’ll have time to polish all the jagged bits while I can focus on it. Plus, there’s the importance of the campaign, that’s of the utmost importance right now.  I think I’m going to be taking a Quora break. When I hit that 30,000 word-in-a-day mark, I’ll come back and edit this answer with something more precise. I predict with breaks and whatnot, it’ll be around 12–14 hours, no matter what I do. And I think that’s a good limit for human capacity. I think if I take a 2-hour nap when I hit that 20,000 mark, I can get in that other 10,000 without causing issues for the next day. I might be able to hit 5000 words an hour. If I can hold that for six hours, I’ll be fine, but I don’t think that’s reality. We shall see how my week proceeds…
